**Chapter IV**

"You might remember—I told you before," Svidrigaïlov started, "that I was in debt and stuck in prison for a huge amount of money, with no hope of paying it back. I won't go into details about how Marfa Petrovna got me out. Can you believe how crazy a woman can be in love? She was a good woman and very smart, even though she didn't have much education. 

Would you believe that this honest and jealous woman, after many emotional fights and complaints, agreed to a sort of deal with me that she kept during our whole marriage? She was much older than me, and she always had a clove or something in her mouth. I was honest enough to tell her that I couldn't be completely faithful to her. This made her very upset, but she seemed to appreciate my brutal honesty. She thought it meant I didn't want to trick her, which is important for a jealous woman. 

After a lot of tears, we made an unwritten agreement: first, I would never leave Marfa Petrovna and would always be her husband; second, I would never be away without her permission; third, I would never take a permanent mistress; fourth, in return for..."

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov recounts the unconventional contract he made with his wife, Marfa Petrovna, regarding fidelity and their marriage dynamics.
